journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Eigensolution of piezoelectric energy harvesters with geometric discontinuities: Analytical modeling and validation

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, George Washington University, Washington, DC, USA

author-notes.corresp: Adam M Wickenheiser, Department of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, George Washington University, 801 22nd St. NW, Washington, DC 20052, USA. Email: amwick@gwu.edu

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on: ASME 2011 Conference on Smart Materials, Adaptive Structures and Intelligent Systems (SMASIS), Symposium on Modeling, Simulation and Control: Part 1

abstract.p: Although cantilevered beams are the most prolific design for resonant piezoelectric energy harvesters, other topologies have been studied for their compactness or conformability to their host structures’ geometry. These more complex structures have been analyzed using custom analytical models developed from the first principles or finite-element methods to compute their eigensolutions and piezoelectric coupling effects. This article discusses the use of the transfer matrix method to derive analytical solutions to beam structures with pointwise discontinuities, bends, or lumped inertias between members or at the tip. Euler–Bernoulli beam theory is used to derive transfer matrices for the uniform beam segments, and point transfer matrices are derived to handle discontinuities in the structure between beam segments. The eigensolution of the transfer matrix is shown to produce the natural frequencies and mode shapes for these structures. Subsequently, the electromechanical coupling effects are incorporated, and the base excitation problem is considered. Parametric case studies are provided for beam structures with varying piezoelectric layer coverage and angle between members. Finally, these results are compared to finite-element solutions using COMSOL, and the modeling discrepancies are discussed. Based on the favorable comparison between these two methods, the utility and accuracy of the transfer matrix method are proven.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A major problem with resonant vibration–based energy harvesters is that their peak power occurs near the mechanical resonant frequencies of the transducer. In order to shrink the size and mass of these devices while reducing their natural frequencies, a variety of techniques have been employed. For example, changing the standard cantilevered beam geometry and manipulating the mass distribution along the beam have been investigated. Designing the structure with a continuously varying cross section (Dietl and Garcia, 2010; Reissman et al., 2007; Roundy et al., 2005) and tuning the ratio of the tip mass to beam mass (Dietl and Garcia, 2010; Wickenheiser, 2011a) have been shown to increase the electromechanical coupling of the device, a measure of how much energy is successfully harvested per cycle. Changing the number and location of piezoelectric patches along the beam can also increase the coupling by focusing on where the greatest strain energy is found (Guyomar et al., 2005; Wu et al., 2009). Multibeam structures can shrink the overall dimensions of a structure by folding it in on itself while minimizing the increase in fundamental natural frequency (Karami and Inman, 2011); they can also increase effective bandwidth by clustering natural frequencies together (Berdy et al., 2011; Erturk et al., 2009). A nonlinear technique called “frequency up-conversion” also shows promise to boost power at frequencies well below resonance (Murray and Rastegar, 2009; Tieck et al., 2006; Wickenheiser and Garcia, 2010b). Despite the prevalence of widely varying designs, no single analytic method exists for predicting the electromechanical behavior of all of these systems.

In the energy harvesting literature, the piezoelectric transducer is commonly modeled as a lumped, single-degree-of-freedom (DOF) system. To better predict the dynamics of energy harvesters, models have been developed based on their geometry and material properties. Two common approaches to modeling and simulating these devices are lumped parameter (typically single DOF) (DuToit et al., 2005; Roundy and Wright, 2004) and distributed parameter (multi-DOF) (DuToit et al., 2005; Erturk and Inman, 2008; Sodano et al., 2004; Wickenheiser and Garcia, 2010a) models. Lumped parameter models are simple and effective when vibrating near a resonant frequency, and experimental data are available to estimate the model parameters. Distributed parameter models are more accurate, can predict geometric effects such as charge cancellation, and can be easily extended to include arbitrary DOFs. However, these models are much more complex, are designed for a specific geometry, and require experimental determination of some of their parameters.

In this article, a straightforward analytic approach is taken for modeling beams of varying cross-sectional geometry; multiple discontinuities, including lumped masses; and angles between members, which correctly account for the changes in the mechanical response to adding piezoelectric layers with partial coverage to the structure. This method is derived from the classical transfer matrix method (TMM) (Pestel and Leckie, 1963) combined with an existing model for constant cross section, Euler–Bernoulli beam energy harvesters (Wickenheiser and Garcia, 2010a). Transfer matrices have been employed in calculating the natural frequencies and mode shapes of fanfolded or zigzag structures with 180° bends (Karami and Inman, 2011; Reissman and Garcia, 2008); however, in this article, these methods are extended to arbitrary angles between members. An advantage of this method is that increasing the complexity of the structure does not increase the size of the eigenvalue problem required to find the natural frequencies and mode shapes. Furthermore, the same formulation can be used for an arbitrary distribution of lumped masses and varying geometry beam segments.

In the following sections, the equations of motion (EOMs) are derived for uniform beam segments and for lumped masses. Subsequently, it is shown how these subsystems can be combined to form an arbitrarily complex structure. The eigenvalue problem for an arbitrary design is then solved for the natural frequencies and mode shapes. These solutions are incorporated into a partial differential equation (PDE) model that includes the linearized piezoelectric constitutive equations, enabling these equations to be decoupled by mode and solved. Finally, a few simple case studies are presented to highlight the usefulness of this technique. The results obtained are compared to finite-element analysis (FEA) eigensolutions, and the discrepancies between the two are addressed.

sec.title: Electromechanical system model using transfer matrices
Overview of TMM
sec.p: The TMM used in this study is derived from the methodology described in Pestel and Leckie (1963). This method is used to calculate the natural frequencies and mode shapes of piecewise continuous structures, such as the one shown in Figure 1. This figure shows a three-segment beam with lumped masses connected to the tip1 of each segment. Each segment is assumed to have constant geometric and material properties, meaning that the beam cross sections remain constant along the length of the segment; however, different segments may have different properties. Furthermore, each segment may have a different number and arrangement of piezoelectric and substructure layering, as shown in Figure 1.

caption.p: Layout and geometric parameters of an example piecewise continuous structure. The x-direction is measured along the polygonal line traversing all of the beam segments. The y-direction is always perpendicular in the transverse direction. This example shows two different bimorph segments followed by a unimorph segment.

The form of equation (5b) also reveals another feature of the TMM: no matter how many beam segments and lumped masses there are in the structure, the problem never grows beyond a 6 × 6 linear system. Adding more beam segments or lumped masses merely increases the number of 6 × 6 matrices in products like the one appearing in equation (5b).

sec.title: Field transfer matrix derivation
sec.p: To derive the state transition matrix between two points along a uniform beam segment, Euler–Bernoulli beam assumptions are employed, dropping the electromechanical coupling effects and the inertial forces due to base excitation. This is equivalent to finding the free response of the beam segment and assuming Euler–Bernoulli beam shapes, a prevalent simplification appearing in the literature (DuToit et al., 2005; Erturk and Inman, 2008; Wickenheiser and Garcia, 2010a). Although a nonzero voltage causes an internal bending moment at the boundaries, this is ignored at this stage of the modeling. Furthermore, it is assumed that the beam is rigid in the axial direction, which is a valid assumption if the beam is relatively thin in the transverse direction.
Consider the free-body diagram shown in Figure 2. Dropping higher order terms, balances of forces remove, and moments yield

caption.p: Free-body diagram of Euler–Bernoulli beam segment.

sec.title: Point transfer matrix derivation
sec.p:
The point transition matrix
P
is now derived, which models the discontinuities in the states between the uniform beam segments. These discontinuities can be caused by lumped masses or bends in the beam, which cause a jump in the internal forces and moment. Consider the free-body diagram of the lumped mass shown in Figure 3. This mass is considered a point mass with mass
m

sec.title: Eigensolution using the system transfer matrix
Natural frequencies
sec.p:
As discussed in the preceding section “Overview of TMM,” the state transition matrix
Φ (
x
2
,
x
1
)
relates the states of the system between any points along the beam through equation (2). Regardless of the locations of
x
1
and
x
2
, the transition matrix is expressible as a product of field and point transfer matrices, as illustrated by equation 5(a) and (b). This representation is due to the semigroup property of the state transition matrix: the path between two distinct points can be divided into segments, and the overall transition matrix is just the product of the transition matrices of the segments. The number of matrices in this product is equal to the sum of the number of beam segments and the number of junctions between the two endpoints of the path.

It should be noted, however, that at this point in the analysis, the natural frequency
ω
is still unknown; thus,
Φ (
x
2
,
x
1
)
cannot be evaluated between any two arbitrary points. Nevertheless, the boundary conditions at the ends of the structure provide locations where some of the states are known. In the presently studied cantilever (or “fixed-free”) configuration, the following states are known at the boundaries

where n is the total number of beam segments. These boundary conditions signify a fixed condition at
x = 0
and a free condition at
x =
L
n
. To relate the fixed and free ends, equation (4) is employed between these points, yielding

where
U
, the product of all of the point and field transfer matrices (a result of the semigroup property of
Φ
), is called the system transfer matrix. This matrix is the state transition matrix from the fixed end to the free end, across all of the beam segments and junctions. Since each field and point transfer matrix is a function of
ω
2
(c.f. equations (11) and (18)), their product,
U
, is therefore a polynomial in
ω
2
. As will be demonstrated, this is the matrix that is used in the eigensolution of the structure.
Substituting equation (19) into equation (20) and examining the second, fifth, and sixth equations of the resulting linear system reveal

where
U
i , j
is the i, j component of the system transfer matrix
U
in equation (20). Solving the characteristic equation of the matrix appearing in equation (21) yields the natural frequencies
ω
of the structure and, hence, the conditions for the existence of nontrivial solutions to equation (21). (This same reasoning is used to find the natural frequencies of the beam by traditional methods.) The resulting characteristic equation can be shown to reduce to the standard eigenvalue formulas for cantilevered beams (with or without tip mass).

sec.title: Mode shapes
sec.p: To compute the mode shapes, equation (4) is again revisited, this time evaluated between the fixed end and an arbitrary point along the structure
The third equation in equation (22) is evaluated for the transverse mode shape
where the constants are computed according to the following conditions:

In equation (23), the scaling factor
M
( 0 )
is not retained; instead, the mode shapes are scaled in order to satisfy the appropriate orthogonality conditions, as discussed in the next section. The axial mode shapes
ψ ( x )
can be evaluated from the first equation in equation (22), yielding an equation similar to equation (23) that is evaluated using the same three cases outlined above.

To summarize the use of the TMM to calculate the natural frequencies and mode shapes of the structure, first the transfer matrices of the individual beam segments and lumped masses are computed using equations (11) and (18), respectively. Subsequently, the system transfer matrix,
U
, is constructed by multiplying the field and point transfer matrices representing each component together, as shown in equation (20). The natural frequencies can then be found from the roots of the characteristic equation of the matrix presented in equation (21). It should be noted that if this matrix is singular, then the entire 6 × 6 system transfer matrix is also singular. The mode shapes are given by equation (23), where the constants are evaluated using components of
U
given in equation (24).

sec.title: Modal decoupling
sec.p: The EOMs for an Euler–Bernoulli beam element have been used to develop the field transfer matrix for a beam segment. Using the TMM, a procedure for calculating the natural frequencies and mode shapes has been derived based on the free response. Now, the frequency response is found by decoupling the PDEs into a system of ordinary differential equations, one for each mode. At this stage, it is also prudent to insert the electromechanical coupling and external forcing due to base excitation. By concatenating the EOMs for each segment (Erturk and Inman, 2008; Wickenheiser and Garcia, 2010a), the following EOMs, which apply everywhere in the entire structure, can be found

where
H
( · )
is the Heaviside step function;
δ ( · )
is the Dirac delta function;
ϑ
j
and
C
j
are the electromechanical coupling coefficient and clamped capacitance of the jth segment, respectively; and
L
j
is the x-coordinate of right end of the segment. The electromechanical coupling introduces two more states, the voltage
v ( t )
and the charge
q ( t )
. They are not independent but can be related through equations governing the external circuit.

The external forcing term
f ( x , t )
appearing in equation (25) represents the applied transverse force/length along the beam segments. In the present scenario, this load is the apparent inertial loading due to the excitation of the base in the vertical direction. Due to rotations at the lumped mass interfaces, the inertial loading is not strictly transverse or axial but has components in both directions. The absolute orientation of each component determines how the base excitation affects it; this orientation is the sum of the relative angles between the joints between the base and the component. The inertial loading is derived in terms of the mass distribution in Wickenheiser (2011b); however, for completeness, the results are reprinted here
where

which can be evaluated inductively. In equation (28),
l
j
is the length of the jth beam segment.

To orthonormalize the mode shapes, the free response is once again considered, that is,
v ( t ) ≡ 0
and
f ( x , t ) ≡ 0
. Substituting the modal decomposition given by equation (1) into equation (25) and assuming a sinusoidal time response gives

x = 0
to

n

where
δ

is the Kronecker delta. If the mode shapes are scaled appropriately such that equation (30) is satisfied, then automatically

is satisfied, thereby decoupling equation (25). Subsequently, the natural frequencies and mode shape functions derived from the TMM can be adopted into existing piezoelectric energy harvester models for evaluating continuous and discontinuous structures.

sec.title: Frequency response functions
sec.p: Once the EOMs are decoupled by mode, the frequency response functions (FRFs) of the structure can be obtained in a straightforward manner by substituting the modal expansions given by equation (1) into equations (25) and (26) and applying the orthogonality conditions given by equations (30) and (31). The decoupled forms of equations (25) and (26) are stated for the rth mode

where equation (32) represents the mechanical equation, in which the modal short-circuit frequencies
ω
r
are equal to the natural frequencies derived from the TMM.2 The modal electromechanical coupling is given by
and the modal influence coefficient of the distributed inertial force along the beam is

Equation (33) represents the electrical dynamics equation when the terminals of the device are assumed to be placed across an external resistor

which in the parallel bimorph configuration is simply the sum of the capacitances of the beam segments. On the right-hand side of the equation (33), the same
Θ

appearing in equation (32) is used to couple the two modal EOMs. It should be noted that only under mass-normalized conditions, that is, equation (30), are these two coupling coefficients equal.

Given that the eigensolution is derived from Euler–Bernoulli beam theory (resulting in a linear PDE), and the piezoelectric constitutive equations are also linearized, the resulting motion and voltage output are also harmonic at the base excitation frequency. Thus, the relative transverse motion at a point

sec.title: Overview
sec.p: In order to demonstrate the use of the TMM for analysis of multisegmented beam structures, a few simple examples are given. Each of the examples given below features a discontinuity in the middle of the beam, which would require distinct modifications to the traditionally derived EOMs. Using the TMM, the same exact solution procedure is used in all cases with only variations in the matrix entries.

In order to validate the TMM, the COMSOL Multiphysics software package, a finite-element–based approach, is also used to compute the natural frequencies and mode shapes of the structures. The geometry is discretized using triangular mesh elements; although their exact size and number vary as the parameters in the case study vary, average values are collected and shown in Table 1. A linear elastic model with isotropic material properties is employed, giving

caption.p: Average FEA domain element statistics.

is the density of the material;
E
is its Young’s modulus; and

is the frequency of the oscillation. Continuity of stress and strain is assumed across all internal boundaries. The eigensolution to equation (39), discretized over the grid, yields the natural frequencies and mode shapes of the structure.

sec.title: Varying piezoelectric layer coverage
sec.p:
The first case study concerns a single cantilevered beam with a bimorph sandwich structure only covering a fraction of the length. Figure 4 depicts the two situations under consideration. Figure 4(a) shows a bimorph beam with varying piezoelectric layer coverage starting from the base and extending to the point
x
div
, the dividing line between the two segments. Note that the point transfer matrix between the two segments, given in equation (18), reduces to the identity matrix in this case. Thus, the system transfer matrix is given by

caption.p: Layout of bimorph structure with partial piezoelectric layer coverage extending (a) from base to tip and (b) from tip to base. (c) The mesh used in FEA simulations.
FEA: finite-element analysis.

U
has the same form in this case, the only difference being the values of

sec.p:
Figures 5 and 6 plot the variation in fundamental (short circuit) natural frequency as
x
div
is varied between 0 and L, the overall length of the structure, and the layer thickness ratio (over the segment with piezoelectric coverage) is varied between
t
p
/
t
s
= 0 . 05
and
t
p
/
t
s
= 3
. For each of these ratios, the thickness of the substructure is held constant at
t
s
= 0 . 75 mm
. In Figure 5, the piezoelectric layers are extended out from the base to
x
div
as in Figure 4(a). These curves indicate that in each case, the beam with full coverage has a higher natural frequency than the beam with no coverage, which agrees with the fact that the effective stiffness
( EI )
increases when the piezoelectric layers are added to the bare substructure. Furthermore, this effect increases with larger layer thickness ratios. Somewhat surprisingly, the natural frequency has a maximum at a point of partial coverage; this maximum shifts toward
x
div
= L
as
t
p
/
t
s
increases. This phenomenon can be explained by considering that the partial coverage makes the beam effectively shorter, since the bare substructure section does not contribute to the stiffness as greatly. Increasing the layer coverage past this maximum effectively lengthens the beam, thus decreasing its natural frequency. Furthermore, the area near the tipis under lower strain than toward the base; hence, its contribution is closer to that of a rigid mass than a flexible member.

caption.p: Variation in fundamental (short circuit) natural frequency with respect to patch coverage (starting from base) and layer thickness ratio.
Variation in fundamental (short circuit) natural frequency with respect to patch coverage (starting from tip) and layer thickness ratio.

sec.p:
In Figure 6, the piezoelectric layers are extended back from the tip to
x
div
as in Figure 4(b). Like Figure 5, these curves indicate that in each case, the beam with full coverage has a higher natural frequency than the beam with no coverage. However, as the coverage increases from the tip back toward the base, the natural frequency decreases in every case and only increases sharply just before full coverage is attained. This phenomenon can be explained by considering that, when partially covered by piezoelectric layers near the tip, the majority of the strain in the beam occurs near the base, where the beam is more flexible. Thus, the bimorph segment effectively acts as a lumped mass on the end of the bare substructure segment. Only when the coverage approaches the base do the extra layers contribute strongly to the effective stiffness of the structure.

In Tables 3 and 4, the natural frequencies computed using the TMM are listed alongside those computed from the FEA in COMSOL. First, these results indicate an excellent agreement between the two methods in calculating the fundamental (first mode) natural frequencies in each case; the largest reported relative error is 0.58% for the case
x
div
/ L = 0 . 25
. Furthermore, the error is greater for higher modes, which is consistent with the fact that shear effects become larger as the third spatial derivative increases. The cases
x
div
/ L = 0
and
x
div
/ L = 1
correspond to zero and full piezoelectric layer coverage, respectively. These cases in essence consist of a single-beam segment (only one field transfer matrix); therefore, the TMM reduces exactly to the classical solutions. It is interesting to note that the highest relative errors in modes 4–6 occur in the case
x
div
/ L = 1
, indicating the failure of the Euler–Bernoulli assumptions to account for shear in these layered structures. The TMM does not seem to introduce any consistent errors; in fact, the discrepancies between the TMM and FEA are lower in some cases where there is no classical solution. Thus, any errors introduced by the TMM assumptions appear to be on the same order of magnitude as the errors introduced by Euler–Bernoulli beam theory.

caption.p: Natural frequencies (Hz), varying coverage from base to tip.

fn.p: TMM: transfer matrix method; FEA: finite-element analysis.

caption.p: Natural frequencies (Hz), varying coverage from tip to base.

fn.p: TMM: transfer matrix method; FEA: finite-element analysis.

sec.p:
To quantify the effects of varying piezoelectric layer coverage on the transduction capabilities, the dimensionless electromechanical coupling coefficient is employed. The device (i.e. entire structure) coupling coefficient for the rth mode is given by
k
e

, a term that has appears in nondimensionalized power equations in the literature (e.g. Liao and Sodano, 2008; Shu and Lien, 2006; Wickenheiser and Garcia, 2010a). It has been shown by Wickenheiser (2011a) that this term can be written in the form

for single segment beams (with or without tip mass), where

is the piezoelectric (dimensionless) material coupling coefficient,
κ

is a dimensionless term that depends on the distribution of inertia between the beam and tip mass, and
κ

is a dimensionless term that depends on the effective stiffness of the beam.

In this case study, the ratio
k
e
2
/
k
t
2
is plotted, isolating the effects of geometry on the electromechanical coupling of the device. In Figure 7, the piezoelectric layers are extended out from the base to
x
div
. As the coverage decreases to 0,
k
e
2
/
k
t
2
→ 0
as expected. In this limit, the piezoelectric coverage vanishes and, hence, so does the electromechanical coupling. As the coverage increases, there is a maximum before
x
div
= L
, similar to Figure 5. This indicates that the extra coverage at the end of the beam is not utilized efficiently, which can be explained by the relative lack of strain there. Much like its contribution to the fundamental frequency, the extra coverage near the tip where strain is small effectively acts like dead weight, which only increases the coupling coefficient slightly, similar to adding a tip mass (Wickenheiser, 2011a). The increased coverage, on the other hand, results in a linear increase in the intrinsic capacitance
C
0
, thereby resulting in a decrease in
k
e
2
. In Figure 8, the piezoelectric layers are extended back from the tip to
x
div
. In this case, the ratio
k
e
2
/
k
t
2
is relatively small until the piezoelectric layer coverage approaches full. Reiterating the discussion concerning Figure 6, the majority of the bimorph segment acts like a lumped mass with no internal strain; thus, it does not contribute to the electromechanical coupling.

caption.p: Variation in coupling coefficient ratio with respect to patch coverage (starting from base) and layer thickness ratio.
Variation in coupling coefficient ratio with respect to patch coverage (starting from tip) and layer thickness ratio.

sec.p:
FRFs for the device shown in Figure 4(a) are shown in Figures 9 and 10. The resistor value chosen for this study is the optimal value for energy harvesting at the fundamental frequency in the limit of small electromechanical coupling, that is,
R
l
= 1 / (
C
0
ω
1
)
(DuToit et al., 2005; Liao and Sodano, 2008; Wickenheiser and Garcia, 2010a). This term appears in equation (38), the FRF for voltage, and hence affects all of the other FRFs. To isolate the effects of piezoelectric layer coverage, a single-layer thickness ratio,
t
p
/
t
s
= 2
, is chosen. Furthermore, the frequencies plotted along the x-axes of Figures 9 and 10 are normalized by the fundamental frequency of each structure to avoid the wide spread of resonant peaks predicted by Figure 5, for ease of plotting.

sec.p:
Figure 9 shows the FRF of the tip deflection relative to the base excitation amplitude. These curves indicate that the more flexible beams (with less coverage) have a higher amplitude response at resonance, indicating a lower damping ratio. For the beams with intermediate coverage (
x
div
= 0 . 05
and
x
div
= 0 . 075
), the second natural frequency approaches the first. This indicates that the bare substructure segment vibrates out of phase with the bimorph segment at a relatively low frequency. Power, normalized by
Y
2
ω
3
, is plotted in Figure 10. The highest peak power is achieved at the first resonance frequency by the beam with the most piezoelectric coverage, which is expected given the strain distribution. For harvesting energy from the second mode, the half coverage beam performs the best; this indicates that significant charge cancellation occurs in the beams with greater coverage due to the node in the second mode. The lowest coverage beams generally perform the poorest but may find a use for harvesting from higher modes. The proportion of power gain from the increased mass of the higher coverage beams is not investigated here but could be a topic for future research.

sec.title: Varying center angle
sec.p:
The second case study concerns a cantilevered bimorph beam with a varying joint angle at the center, as depicted in Figure 11(a). The corresponding FEA mesh is shown in Figure 11(b). Both beam segments are identical in length, cross section, and material properties, which are listed in Table 2. The overall length of the structure is kept constant while the center angle is varied. The special case
θ
1
=
0
∘
corresponds to a standard cantilevered bimorph, whereas the case
θ
1
=
90
∘
corresponds to an L-shaped structure, previously studied by Erturk et al. (2009). In this case, the system transfer matrix has the form
U =
F
2
P
1
F
1
, where

caption.p: (a) Layout of bimorph structure with varying center joint angle. (b)The mesh used in FEA simulations. The inset shows the detail of the segment connections. The angle of the connection is fixed using an internal boundary condition.
FEA: finite-element analysis.

sec.p:
where
x
div
= L / 2
and

Figures 12 to 14 show the results of the center joint angle parameter study for the design depicted in Figure 11(a). In this study, the center joint angle
θ
1
is varied between 0° and 180°. Both beam segments are identical bimorphs. As with the case of varying piezoelectric layer coverage, increasing the piezoelectric layer thickness increases the bending stiffness and, therefore, the natural frequencies when all other parameters are held constant, as shown in Figure 12. This plot also indicates that the fundamental frequency increases with center joint angle, which causes an effective shortening of the beam. Figure 13 shows the variation in the ratio of the first two natural frequencies,
ω
2
/
ω
1
. First, these results indicate that this ratio is independent of the thickness ratio of the layers; this result is confirmed by Wickenheiser (2011a), where it is shown that this ratio is only a function of the ratio of nondimensional eigenvalues of the device. Moreover, as the device is folded back on itself, that is, as
θ
1
increases, the first natural frequency increases while the second decreases, both converging to a common value. This phenomenon of “repeated resonances” in structures composed of identical beams folded back on each other has previously been investigated by Khattak et al. (2006). As mentioned by Erturk et al. (2009), this convergence is useful for broadband energy harvesting from a range of excitation frequencies between these two natural frequencies since either mode has a chance of being excited. Furthermore, energy exchange between modes becomes possible when the natural frequencies are commensurable (Nayfeh and Mook, 1979), a useful mechanism for exciting a higher frequency mode from a lower frequency excitation. Finally, Figure 14 indicates that the coupling coefficient is relatively insensitive to center joint angle. This insensitivity is mainly due to the small impact on the strain at the root, where most of the energy is harvested, by the rotation of the relatively strain-free tip segment.

caption.p: Variation in the fundamental (short circuit) natural frequency with respect to center joint angle and layer thickness ratio.
Variation in the ratio of the first two natural frequencies with respect to center joint angle and layer thickness ratio.
Variation in the coupling coefficient ratio with respect to center joint angle and layer thickness ratio.

sec.p:
In Table 5, the natural frequencies computed using the TMM are listed alongside those computed from the FEA in COMSOL. As in the previous case, these results indicate an excellent agreement between the two methods in calculating the fundamental (first mode) natural frequencies in each case. The error is seen to be higher in this case (however, still below 1.5%) due to modeling differences at the center joint. In the TMM, this joint is modeled as a rigid point connection between two one-dimensional Euler–Bernoulli beams. In the FEA, the loads carried across the point connection cause a local stress concentration, deforming both beams at the connection. In order to mitigate this effect, the point connection is replaced by an overlap region, shown in the inset of Figure 11(b), where no relative motion between members is allowed, thus preserving the angles between them. Although this reduces the effect of the stress concentration, it cannot be completely eliminated in FEA where there is such a sharp angle. Additionally, the discrepancy is greater for higher modes, when Euler–Bernoulli assumptions are more erroneous. The highest error, 5.94%, is found to be in the sixth mode for
θ
1
=
45
∘
; however, this is probably an anomaly since the next highest error is 3.78%. Like the previous case, the errors in the natural frequency computation are of a consistent order of magnitude, suggesting that the TMM solution is as good an approximation as the Euler–Bernoulli equations.

caption.p: Natural frequencies (Hz), varying center joint angle.

fn.p: TMM: transfer matrix method; FEA: finite-element analysis.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article presents an electromechanical modeling technique for computing the eigensolution and frequency transfer functions for segmented beams using the TMM. This method allows for multiple discontinuities in the beam structure, for example, partial layer coverage, discontinuities in cross section, angles between members, and multiple lumped masses along the length. Transfer functions are derived for each continuous segment and each discontinuity, and a system transfer function is described using the semigroup property of state transition matrices. This procedure produces the natural frequencies and mode shapes that can subsequently be used to decouple the electromechanical EOMs for the structure.

The TMM is general enough to be effective at analyzing many configurations of piezoelectric structures without requiring a rederivation of the governing equations starting from first principles. During the course of the derivation, it is shown that although the axial and transverse dynamics may be decoupled for a single-beam segment, they become coupled at angled connections between members. Furthermore, it is shown that the size of the eigenvalue problem does not grow with added complexity to the structure, unlike finite-element methods. In this article, this method is applied to structures with partial piezoelectric layer coverage, taking into account the discontinuity in cross section at the end of the piezoelectric layers. Additionally, variations in center joint angle are discussed, including the special cases of L-shaped (
θ =
90
∘
) and reflex (
θ =
180
∘
) beams. The natural frequencies, coupling coefficients, and displacement and power frequency responses are computed and discussed, proving the versatility of the TMM. The accuracy of the method is confirmed by comparing these results to those computed through FEA. In all case studies herein, a maximum error of 1.42% is found in the fundamental natural frequency, and a maximum error of 5.94% is found in the sixth natural frequency. Therefore, this new method can be used to accurately predict the first few modes of a complex piezoelectric beam structure.

fn.p: In this article, the “base” of each segment is the end closest to the host structure, whereas the “tip” is the end furthest. Distance between points of the structure is measured along the polygonal line starting at the host and continuing to the end of the structure. As shown in Figure 1, the segments are numbered starting from the segment that adjoins the host structure.

Setting
v ( t ) ≡ 0
, that is, shorting the terminals of the device, is equivalent to decoupling the electrical from the mechanical dynamics.
